entry.title: Week 1
entry.content:
I‚Äôve been thinking for a while about setting this up, and this week seems as good as any. Both Alice and Frances have weekly updates that are a joy to read. Jenn has a live laugh blog. Maybe this is the year of long form tweets?

I haven‚Äôt touched my site in like 6+ months so when I tried to run jekyll locally it obviously didn‚Äôt work, so what you‚Äôre reading took like 40 commits on GitHub.

In work news, I‚Äôm coming back to Magenta after 6 months of being a fellow with the Trevor project. I lead a team that worked on classifying suicidal ideation for one of their projects. The work was super interesting (though often sad), and in a shocking development i really enjoyed being a team lead. I think that even though I‚Äôm really good at writing actual code, I‚Äôm also good at herding cats and holding a lot of statuses and details in my head. I was worried at the beginning of the fellowship that TLs don‚Äôt write any code and I would suddenly become a meeting chair, and even though I did have a ton of meetings, I also wrote a ton of code. I know it‚Äôs weird to hear a woman assert things she‚Äôs good at it. This is also a new thing I‚Äôm trying out. My notes, my rules!

In personal news, I‚Äôve gotten really into broth-as-a-savoury-afternoon tea. I used to make a lot of miso (and drink it out of a cup; this part is key), but to add some variety in my life, this week I started boiling a bunch of vegetables during meetings and making my own broth. Anything for variety in the apocalypse, amirite.

Goldie moved in to my Animal Crossing island.

I am exclusively watching serial killer shows right now (Des, I‚Äôll be gone in the dark, Ripper) which isn‚Äôt exactly off brand but might be a little TOO on brand, you know? That‚Äôs what I get for finishing Bridgerton in 2 days.

For my birthday in November my mum got me some new books of piano sheet music, so I‚Äôve started playing some piano again. Before I moved to America, I used to play every day and be actually good at it, but much like with everything else I got really burnt out by the stress of ‚Äúbeing good at a hobby‚Äù and started hating it. I think enough time has passed that I can give it a try again, and maybe I won‚Äôt be so intense this time. I‚Äôm currently trying to nail Bach‚Äôs Menuet in G. Here is my coworker playing around with it.

A lot of you JINXED this year like the jinxers you are because shit was looking good on Tuesday, and lo and behold by Wednesday the world was on fire again and I was sad and just watched the news in horror.

entry.title: Week 2
entry.content:
• Still into soups: I made a bomb cream of broccoli. I also bought a new vegan broth base to fuck with because buying the cartons of broth is like buying bottled water aka: bad and wasteful.

  • My dog‚Äôs skin is turning grey. I know this sounds funny but it‚Äôs like, a thing. There could be a number of reasons for this, but the most likely one is that she‚Äôs an inbred dumbass and allergic to something in her food, like chicken. Or she could be dying. In any case, she‚Äôs now on Fancy Food‚Ñ¢Ô∏è which makes her insufferable. Related: pet nutrition is absolutely bonkers.

  • If you‚Äôre trying to gauge what level of pandemic mental breakdown I‚Äôm at, I dyed my hair pastel pink in the bathroom last week (Manic Panic blessing my life since 2001), and this week I ‚Äúrescued‚Äù a very sad looking croton from the grocery shop. I got emotional that it was ugly and unloved and nobody else was going to care for it because people only buy pretty plants, so I HAD to adopt it. I paid 3$ for this privilege of bringing a plant with broken leaves into my house.

  • New season of drag race! I know this will be very polarizing, but I kind of love how insane Utica is. I also love Gottmik (and that Ru has finally pivoted to saying ‚Äúand may the best drag queen win‚Äù) and Tamisha. Still don‚Äôt understand the pork chop gimmick, and I haven‚Äôt eaten a pork chop in like a year and a half so it makes me hungry.

  • I had some really good meetings at work with super creative and inspiring people, and it‚Äôs spilling into my personal life: I have 2 (TWO) ideas for generative art projects, and 0 (ZERO) motivation to actually do them. I also haven‚Äôt finished the Bach Menuet I started last week. What do I do instead with my evenings you ask? Watch every single Trixie Mattel video on YouTube because that‚Äôs the journey I‚Äôm on.

entry.title: Week 3
entry.content:
• Monday was off which ruined any routine I had formed. I barely got used to waking up on Mondays to go to work and then bam, 2 weeks in, a Monday off. I had dreams all week about working part time, probably because my brain is clinging desperately to this hope of not having to ever wake up on Mondays.

  • I got 3 aquatic snails in a small little aquarium. They live next to my laptop so I can look at them during the boring meetings, and they don‚Äôt seem to have any worries. Tentative names: Shelly, Shelmet, Tickle me Shelmo. They‚Äôre super active around noon, and I‚Äôm learning that whatever number of tentacles I thought a snail had, it‚Äôs incorrect. I am obsessed with them.

  • We had an absolutely awful ER adventure with our dog. On Saturday night she was really ill all of a sudden: she couldn‚Äôt stand without falling over, couldn‚Äôt stop throwing up, and her nose was super hot (this is how you can check if a dog has a fever!). Since she‚Äôs golden retriever and therefore a trash vacuum, we were almost positive she ate a poisonous mushroom, or some coffee beans or chocolate or something bad like that. Imagine our shock when the ER did a tox screen and it came back positive for‚Ä¶.MDMA. Best guess right now is that someone at the airbnb next door (who hosts a lot of dubious frat boys) threw something in our fenced-in yard. In any case, dogs shouldn‚Äôt be on hard drugs, and she had a pretty rough rave of IV fluids and ice packs all night. Now I‚Äôm too freaked out to let her outside in the yard and have some empathy towards the mothers who want to lock their childrens in the bedrooms and never leave them out of their sight. What a shitty thing to do to a dog, man.

  • I am reading ‚ÄúBecause Internet‚Äù by my second favourite linguist, Gretchen McCulloch. My favourite linguist is Jane Solomon; she also wrote a book, ‚ÄúThe Dictionary of Difficult Words‚Äù, and 7 year old me would‚Äôve thought it was the absolutely best ever. If you have a smart ass 7 year old, buy it for them.

  • I see some progress in my watercolours. Do‚Äôs: layer blobs of colours, but only after the previous one has completely dried. Dont‚Äôs: No aggressive blending or gradients that aren‚Äôt just ‚Äúthis colour bled into this other one‚Äù.

entry.title: Week 4
entry.content:
• Tahoe (where we currently live during this pannie-d) got a ton of snow this week, so I‚Äôve been in winter mode. Went skiing on Friday, went snowshoeing on Sunday. My calves are on fire. Skiing is pretty safe; everyone is wearing masks, they‚Äôve closed all the lodges, and tbh nobody should be within 6 feet of me skiing on a good day.

  • I can tell when I accidentally overdo it with the hobbies (which is every time I get excited about a new hobby) because I rapidly swing in the other direction. I painted nothing this week, and I spent all weekend watching the entire season of Bling Empire in one day instead.

  • I knitted most of a hat and then unravelled it all because it had accumulated too many mistakes. It‚Äôs a really fun knit so I‚Äôm not too bothered.

  • I spent a lot of evenings frantically working on a visualization about plastic waste (new hobby alert) that nobody asked for. It started as ‚Äúlemme do a quick thing to get better at d3 and at asking questions about the data‚Äù and it‚Äôs now a good 8+ hours of work in. Sure wish I would‚Äôve half assed it, because now it‚Äôs not done and I don‚Äôt really want to finish it.

  • Still reading ‚ÄúBecause Internet‚Äù; also started The Travelling Cat Chronicles.

  • I am really irritated and confused by this Hangouts/Chat situation. I am on an iPhone, and want to send Frances stupid links, hot takes and photos. We can‚Äôt use our respective phone‚Äôs Messages app (because hers is over SMS which shits the bed on photos, and mine is Apple proprietary). We were using Hangouts, but it‚Äôs deprecated, and wanted to use Chat, but it‚Äôs ‚Ä¶ enterprise only and peons can‚Äôt start new conversations? Also Whatsapp is evil and Signal spams all my contacts when I install it. What the fuck, I just want to talk to non-Apple friends in 2021.

  • February is a perfect calendar rectangle and that is satisfying.

  • Are week notes the new LiveJournal but without comments? Discuss.

entry.title: Week 6
entry.content:
• I skipped week 5 because all I did in the panna cotta was watch 3 seasons of ‚Äúhow to get away with murder‚Äù. It‚Äôs a terrible show and I‚Äôm not ashamed of it.

  • What is up with that star codex thing? I can‚Äôt believe there was a cult of assholes in tech I didn‚Äôt know about. I‚Äôm obviously not surprised they existed, there‚Äôs an asshole under every rock in tech; I‚Äôm just surprised I didn‚Äôt know about it. I‚Äôm a person in the know! I have an invite to Dispo!

  • I watched the #freebritney documentary and I think that a) the concept of a conservatorship for a grown ass 40 year old woman is fucked and b) her dad being a mysoginistic asshole is 80% of the reason she‚Äôs on one. Nobody put Kanye in a corner when he was going bonkers; we let him run for president and bought his shitty 20 minute long album to make fun of it and talked about how he prolly needs to take his meds but oh well, famous people amirite. But if a woman goes a bit bonkers and in the process shaves her head (we all know women aren‚Äôt allowed to shave their heads), then suddenly she needs to be in a legal monetary prison for life? Rich people waste their money ALL the time, why is she the different one? Makes you think.

  • I also think it‚Äôs the cherry on the cake that because her dad is ‚Äúmanaging‚Äù her estate she is essentially paying both for her lawyers to try to help her, and for the opposing lawyers to try to screw her.

  • I‚Äôve been working on a lot of generative art. This is good, because I‚Äôm making things and I want to open a store so people can put my things on their walls, but bad because when I make art and keep looking at it I end up violently hating it, and that spirals out of control into a ‚Äúeverything I do is basic and derivative‚Äù mood which tbh makes me feel like shit. I had a nice chat with @mrmrs who is 100x more talented than me but feels similarly about his art sometimes, so I felt very seen.

  • We drove to Arizona this weekend. We are still doing nothing but now it‚Äôs nothing around cactuses and the desert. I‚Äôve been trying to find ways to get myself to move more, and I read in Alice‚Äôs notes that she tried out geocaching, so I installed an app last night! I thought there would be like a geocache per state, but there‚Äôs millions. There are 2 geocaches within a 2 mile walk! If there‚Äôs no week 7 notes it‚Äôs either because nothing happened or because I died trying to get to this cache. The halting problem is a hell of a thing.

entry.title: Week 7
entry.content:
• I got deep into geocaching, friends. I found 3 caches in Arizona! I didn‚Äôt sign any of them because I kept forgetting to bring a pen, so now nobody will know I was there.

  • Geocaching is mad in the US. We drove back from Arizona (flying? in this economy??), and there were HUNDREDS along the highway. First, who are these people that stop on the side of the highway to hide a cache? Second, who are these people who stop on the side of the highway to go look for a cache? Were you raised by wolves? Highways are dangerous yo, don‚Äôt just stop on the shoulder unless your car is on fire.

  • I am filled with fury about cryptoart. FILLED. I follow someone on Instagram who has raised money for the national park service, and loves Joshua Tree, and a lot of her art is of nature, and she‚Äôs been minting like 3 NFTs a week. Joanie Lemercier wrote how 10 seconds of cryptoart used more energy than their studio in 2 years. TWO YEARS. Imagine being an artist that is minting cryptoart in the same week that Texas residents are bankrupt because they couldn‚Äôt pay their $17,000 heating bill in the winter because the Texas utilities companies are messed up and unregulated and can fuck with prices when supply is low. FILLED WITH FURY.

  • Related: I think part of the problem is that we‚Äôre not making people build those absurd rigs to mine crypto anymore.In uni one of my friends built one of those babies to mine doge at home, and he could heat up his house in the winter from it! Now you just sign up for a service that mines in a data center and heats up the desert somewhere.

  • Also related: I 100% empathize with artists that selling art is hard and it‚Äôs impossible to make a living, but as with everything, crypto isn‚Äôt gonna solve anything. Unless you have a weird perpetuity clause in your NFT (is that a thing? I don‚Äôt know. I make it a point to know as little as possible about crypto because I already have heartburn from regular life things and don‚Äôt need more), the only people making money from cryptoart are the people who could already sell regular art for a shit ton of money. Otherwise nobody is going to pay any real money for your anonymous neon animated block, crypto or not.

  • I tweeted about this AND I now wrote about it and I am still filled with fury. Sorry to the 2 people who read these notes and also read this on Twitter. Nobody better email me about this; I cannot be convinced to not hate crypto, and I will just mute you with high prejudice and no guilt.

  • Honestly now that I am typing out these notes I‚Äôm also filled with fury about everything that‚Äôs going on with Google and Research, so I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve done anything other than be angry all week. lol what a time to be alive.

  • In the spare rage free seconds I‚Äôve had left, I have been hard at work at getting meownica studio up and running. I have a special instagram account. I took the actual store out of maintenance mode. I enlisted my photographer friend Ashley (she is enormously talented, please hire her) to take photos so that I can update the store with real life product photos. This week is the week, I feel it.

  • Also canvas-sketch is dope and it does dope things (like use units that make sense)

entry.title: Week 8
entry.content:
• This week was entirely consumed by the fact that I opened an online store to sell generative ‚Äúart‚Äù prints. Art is in quotations here because I have a deeply unhealthy relationship with calling anything I do art, or myself an artist, but we don‚Äôt have time to for a therapy session right now.

  • It went really great. I sold out of 2 kinds of prints! People who weren‚Äôt just my friends put it orders! My first customer ever was Mariko, which is absurd because she should‚Äôve gotten a free print without even asking based on the kilograms of gacha she‚Äôs brought me from Japan, but of course she was also the first one to see the tweet about the store because that‚Äôs just the kind of friend she is.

  • (this paragraph is really niche and boring, skip it). Every once in a while I use a software that blows my fucking mind. E-commerce is generally NOT this experience btw, because it‚Äôs all integrations that are 90% magic and 10% wonky af. Like, my store is a BigCartel store (big fan!), but the site itself is a bit flaky so sometimes Things Will Happen‚Ñ¢ (like pages won‚Äôt redirect, the theme editor will just panic, javascript is a prison). Stripe was like 95% magic and 5% ‚Äúthe oauth flow didn‚Äôt redirect well For Reasons‚Ñ¢ so I had to do it twice‚Äù. I don‚Äôt even know who was at fault there. Anyway, PirateShip is a thing that prints USPS labels and it was 120% magic. People wrote their addresses in their orders in my store; I clicked a single button on the PirateShip site, which imported those addresses, made shipping labels, made customs forms for the international orders, formatted all the labels for my label printer to print AND emailed all the customers their tracking numbers. And charged me 0 extra dollars. PirateShip, I don‚Äôt know how you make your money but you are an absolute gem and I love you. The post office gentleman even commented on how together my shit was.

  • Frances and I had a FitBit active minutes challenge and I WON by like 32 minutes (aka extremely close). Zach was also in some Apple Fitness challenge with a friend, so we had several ‚Äúcan we walk to the dog park, I need the points‚Äù moments. The dog had the best week.

  • I am trying to get as good at painting on my iPad as I am in real life (which honestly, is not bad. I am a good technical artist, I‚Äôm just basic and derivative, ya know?). I took some skillshare classes, and I installed a paperfeel screen protector thing that really helped. The shinyness is so offputting for drawing.

  • I finished ‚ÄúDept. of Speculation‚Äù by Jenny Offill. I really enjoyed it. I write book reviews on my goodreads if you‚Äôre looking for a book to read.

  • I‚Äôm watching a lot of Below Deck (like, all the past seasons). I don‚Äôt know what this will do to my personality, but given that it‚Äôs been almost a year of hanging out with pretty much just my pets and Zach, it probably won‚Äôt be an improvement.

  • Spotted: a very fuzzy bee smelling the flowers (mostly Nasturtiums it turns out) from the bee-friendly seeds I planted last year. You know you love me, xoxo garden girl.

entry.title: Week 10
entry.content:
• I took the whole week off because I was very tired of life. It‚Äôs the year anniversary of the last time the world was normal and it‚Äôs bringing me down. Between covid and immigration delays it‚Äôs looking very 50/50 on whether I can attend my closest cousin‚Äôs wedding this fall in Romania, and I‚Äôm beyond gutted at the thought of missing it. All I can do about it is wait, and that‚Äôs making the pandemic fatigue worse by a thousand.

  • I made two prints of Barnsley ferns. They looked cool in the end, but they were a bit of a struggle. Barsnley ferns are these super popular fractals that (spoilers) look like ferns, but honestly, fractals in general are not my favourite. These ones come out of 4 equations and 6 parameters which sounds like would open a whole world of possibilities, but it turns out most combinations of values produce absolute trash. Which is fine, but that‚Äôs not my style of generative art. Instead, I spent all my random numbers in trying to paint the ferns like furry brush strokes and letters I don‚Äôt think anyone other than me appreciates that üòÖ.

  • I got deep into linocuts. I‚Äôve been trying to figure out how to make the things that come out of a computer also come out of my hands, and hand prints can definitely be that thing. Doing the linocut itself is my favourite kind of relaxing; it keeps my hands busy with stabbing squishy things (also see: that time i picked up felting in meetings). I can‚Äôt believe I haven‚Äôt tried it before. Also, Frances says that the linocuts I‚Äôve been doing look a lot like the kind of carving I used to do with my pottery, which is great news because that means I have a *~style~*.

  • As usual, I am undeservedly lucky: one of my cousins, Raluca Iancu is an enormously talented printmaker and professor of printmaking, so I got to text her with questions. I don‚Äôt think everyone who starts up with a hobby can text a professional in that area and be like ‚Äúhello I bought 10$ tools and some linoleum, please hold my feelings with your 10+ years of domain expertise‚Äù.

  • Zach and I have been babysitting our friends‚Äô smol puppy. Her name is Penny and she is SO CUTE. The cat feels infinitely betrayed.

  • I am reading ‚ÄúWow, no thank you‚Äù by Samantha Irby because she is hilarious and hates people almost as much as I do. I just finished season 4 of Below Deck and I think I need to take a break because I got way too invested in the romantic life of Ben the chef.

  • I am looking for a chill, weekly ‚Äúdraw this‚Äù prompt from instagram. If you‚Äôre reading this and you know one that you‚Äôve used or you like, please let me know!

entry.title: Week 11
entry.content:
• It‚Äôs been another week of people being shit, innit? I know I should be used to this by now, but it never ceases to amaze me the capability people have for violence and evil, and the capability the patriarchy has to excuse it. ‚ÄúDude had a bad day‚Äù? For real real? If that excuse has legs then you‚Äôd expect every uterus-holding person to do at LEAST a murder per year. And yet it‚Äôs always white dudes who haven‚Äôt ever thrown up from cramps or had to deal with birth control hormones that feel they‚Äôre entitled to attention or sex or whatever and go on these racist murder sprees. And they‚Äôre going to continue to as long as the media excuses them as ‚Äúbad days‚Äù, or gives them a platform by encouraging racism and xenophobia. If you‚Äôre a Fox news anchor who‚Äôs ever said the words ‚Äúchina virus‚Äù in the last year‚Ä¶these murders are on you pal. I see you, and I deeply hope you don‚Äôt have a good night of sleep for the rest of your life.

  • I took all this anger and donated to Red Canary Song and also pointlessly stabbed linoleum with it. The goal is to carve things a computer generates, but at the moment that‚Äôs a bit too hard for me (I make the computer generate a lot of lines and uhhh that‚Äôs a lot of cutting), so I‚Äôve been carving some non-generative stuff. They‚Äôre all a bit surrealist, because that is extremely my shit, but I don‚Äôt really know what to do with them.

  • I also don‚Äôt understand my audience. For example, I made this computer plant. I thought it was meh, so I wasn‚Äôt gonna put it up in the store, but after tweeting about it, it ended up selling out in a nanosecond. I made this March Madness basketball beet that‚Äôs like‚Ä¶actually well carved and in two colours and cute and nobody cared. The same happened with the generative stuff ‚Äì the chaos attractors I thought were deeply boring sold out instantly, the wings in flight that I absolutely adore are a no-op. I don‚Äôt get it, y‚Äôall.

  • I am back on my procedural bullshit. Adam has been telling me about the Mentalist for months now, and holy shit: he was right. A++ procedural murders, be back in 7 seasons.

  • Every year I say I‚Äôm going to do a March Madness bracket where I ignore the chalk and just pick it on names and mascots, and every year I think the chalk knows best so I don‚Äôt and get busted on like day 1. I see you Oral Roberts toothpastes and Loyola wolf boys, I should‚Äôve kept you going to the final 4 like I wanted to, eh?

  • Related: defensive fouls in basketball are absolutely bullshit.

  • Zach and I are rewatching all of the Marvel movies in story chronological order. This means that I went on several really productive 4 am YouTube holes of watching Avengers bloopers, every recorded interview with Robert Downey Jr, and that whole Ally McBeal season he was on. Imagine if I could put that kind of energy in watching videos about quantum mechanics or something. Instead, I can tell you that he met his wife when filming Gothika, that Tom Hiddleston couldn‚Äôt stop laughing during that one scene in Avengers 1 when Hulk smashes him into the Stark tower apartment floor, and that Mark Ruffalo is scared of needles so he doesn‚Äôt have the Avengers tattoo everyone else got. WHY AM I THIS WAY.

entry.title: Week 12
entry.content:
• Trying something really revolutionary this week which is ‚Äúdoing nothing‚Äù. Bear with me here. I mean: listening to an audio book and NOT also cleaning the house. Just sitting, listening to that book and doing nothing. WASTING THAT TIME. In this economy??? Yes. Do I dislike the idea? Also yes.

  • Related: I switched to the Samantha Irby (Wow, no thank you) audiobook because a) she narrates it and her voice is great and b) after 365+ days in the panini, a voice that isn‚Äôt my husband‚Äôs is a welcomed blessing.

  • I shipped out 10 linocut prints and (hyperbole) it was the most stressful thing I‚Äôve done. Hand prints are beautiful because they‚Äôre so textured and imperfect and really truly awful because they‚Äôre so textured and imperfect. I basically printed 10 extras so I‚Äôd have something to pick from, and ended up hating all of them. I hope that‚Äôs just my brain, and the people who they went to end up liking them.

  • California is opening up vaccines to all humans after April 15, and I have a vaccine appointment for April 22. It‚Äôs been so long since this started that I‚Äôve lost all hope. I assume something horrible will happen like they‚Äôll change their minds or I‚Äôll show up and they‚Äôll be like ha ha no vaccines for legal aliens or people whose names start with the letter M or they‚Äôll run out or I‚Äôll sleep through the appointment or or or. Welcome to my brain, it is a literal prison.

  • All week I did many linocuts and no JavaScripts, so next week I‚Äôm making a rule to either only carve generated things, or only generate things. In the carving pipeline: a generated bookcase, a generated tree ring. In the coding pipeline: a techno landscape (maybe???) for my friend Daniel, some posters for a conference my friend Jana is organizing. Neither of them read this and that‚Äôs for the best.

  • I bought an art from an artist on Instagram! I don‚Äôt usually like very abstract art, but this one is so bright and happy and I think will look great in our very white-walls apartment. It‚Äôs coming from Malta, a country about which I know very little about (capital: Valetta, location: off the tip of the Italian boot, anything else: no)

  • Big week to be a boat, eh?

entry.title: Week 13
entry.content:
• Calico came out and I finished it in 2 days! It‚Äôs an adorably cute game about running a pet cafe in a fantastical little world. It‚Äôs honestly the kind of game I would make. It has an incredible cooking activity interaction, which I can only describe as ‚Äúshit, this game engine has physics and collision detection, let‚Äôs use it for something!‚Äù. It‚Äôs great. (spoilers if you don‚Äôt want to play it: the interaction is ‚Äúyou turn into a smol person and throw the cooking ingredients that are now bigger than you at a giant bowl‚Äù. it‚Äôs wonderful.)

  • I am now playing Fenyx Rising on the Switch because it looked like a Zelda Breath of the Wild clone and can confirm: it‚Äôs basically BOTW minus cooking plus quality of life improvements (swords don‚Äôt break! more looting and outfits!) and sassy greek gods. Don‚Äôt know how the Ubisoft lawyers managed to sweep that under the rug, but I for one welcome the 50+ hours of gameplay ahead of me.

  • I tried to make a Queen of Puddings desert because I saw it on celebrity bakeoff and like Dizzee Rascal (self proclaimed literal first time baker) managed to follow the recipe and do it so I felt overconfident. My custard didn‚Äôt set; I would‚Äôve come last in the technical challenge. Also, it was WAY too sweet in my opinion, but at least that part wasn‚Äôt my fault.

  • I also made my own homemade kaya! I discovered kaya when I was in Singapore 2 years ago, and it was life changing. A kaya toast set is probably my favourite breakfast concept, and I missed having it since I ran out of the Ya Kun kaya I bought on that trip. Worry no more: I am back on that bullshit.

  • I am doing a 2 week Chloe Ting program, which means I have exercised every day this week. This is a huge record that I am very proud of, because I think exercising is the most boring and awful activity in the universe. I hated every minute of it, but by Sunday the minutes SEEM to at least pass faster? I dunno fam, it‚Äôs not great.

  • I‚Äôve started cross stitching while watching the Mentalist. It feels‚Ä¶oddly relaxing? I have no idea what I‚Äôm going to do with the result of cross stitching though, hang it in a bathroom somewhere? Is it too early to go down the pensioner aesthetic route?

  • The linocut print of generated-with-javascript tree ring is almost done! I‚Äôve been making some test prints, and they‚Äôre cute! I think I‚Äôm going to write a blog post about the process because I am very happy with it!

  • I think summer is coming. Better get that SPF out.

entry.title: Week 14
entry.content:
• Let‚Äôs not bury the lede: I quit my job. After 8 years of working there, Google feels like a very different company than the one I joined, one that aligns less and less with my values, and it was time to move on. It sucks, because my immediate team was a group of wonderful people who do great work; I will miss them, and the work I did, greatly. I haven‚Äôt had a vacation longer than 2 weeks since I was 18-ish, because I worked every summer and was too much of a naive workaholic to think I should take more than 1 week between jobs, so I am giving myself 6 months before I start something new this time around. It‚Äôs stressful to not have a plan, and I am bad at relaxing, but I have full confidence I can learn to overachieve at this as well.

  • Didn‚Äôt I tell y‚Äôall I was worried SOMETHING was going to happen and I wasn‚Äôt going to get my vaccine? Here I am, 3 hours before my J+J stabbie stabby, reading about how my appointment is cancelled because it has an incredibly rare clotting side effect. One that is 10000 more rare than the usual clots women get threatened with for taking birth control and that absolutely nobody blinks an eye at anymore. This feels a lot like fabricated concern; we already don‚Äôt care about women getting blood clots. 1 in over 6 million? Fam, that‚Äôs better odds than getting in a car or not getting e-coli from Chipotle. Stop this.

  • I‚Äôve become very bad at telling stories, which is 100% a result of the panini and not being forced to socialize with people. I‚Äôve noticed several times in recent weeks where I‚Äôm telling a story and can see the life leaving from people‚Äôs eyes. I am bored of what I am saying as I am saying it. I am not ready to move to the midwest yet; I must fix this.

  • This is a very good tweet. Abolish the police already. Stop giving guns to insecure people who think a uniform gives them the right to kill others because of the colour of their skin. Stop giving guns to incompetent people who apparently aren‚Äôt trained enough to tell the difference between a gun and a taser, but are confident they have a right to use either. Stop giving guns to people.

  • I am working on 2 linocuts. I should probably start working on more generative stuff, since JavaScript is my bread and butter and should somehow prove to my future employers I still got it. Or something. I am a deflated balloon after finding out my vaccine was cancelled and writing about yet another dead black man above so I don‚Äôt really know how to end this update on a good note.

entry.title: Week 15
entry.content:
• First week of being funemployed! It was very weird. By Wednesday I had lost track of what day it was, and I kept thinking it was a Saturday. By Friday I was overwhelmed with capitalism guilt and thinking that I HAD to do something to ‚Äústay productive‚Äù. What a fake idea y‚Äôall; it hadn‚Äôt even been a full week of vacation!

  • I got vaccinated!!! I had no side effects other than a very sore arm, which is strange because my immune system is the golden retriever of immune systems and doesn‚Äôt miss a free opportunity to throw a fever on something.

  • Games update: Played ‚ÄúCozy Grove‚Äù (comes on many platforms. I played it on my phone but it‚Äôs also on the switch. It‚Äôa cute Animal Crossing like island game with daily tasks), and ‚ÄúDear Reader‚Äù (I played it on my iPhone. It‚Äôs a very cute literary game where you ‚Äúread‚Äù a book by unscrambling text puzzles in sentences. I‚Äôm super curious about how they summarize the book, because it feels very well done. I ‚Äúread‚Äù Flatland like that, and you totally get the gist of the whole story while obviously not reading the whole book. Pretty neat)

  • I was on a podcast, and it was proper fun. Dan is a really nice and thoughtful interviewer. I was joking with him that I‚Äôve been a bit traumatized by podcasts since this weird show I was on a while back about Web Components, where the hosts wanted to just produce drama and stir shit; I think they even opened up with something like ‚Äúthis could be the Jerry Springer of JavaScript‚Äù and I was like‚Ä¶‚Ä¶am I the pregnant 16 year old without a baby daddy in this story because I think I should be offended. Anyway. This podcast wasn‚Äôt anything like that, and I thoroughly loved being on it.

  • Also my hair looked great.

  • I got to the Big Reveal on the Mentalist and I gotta say: it was very good. Unsual for a procedural show to have like a very strong arc, but this was a thing that was 5 seasons in the making and it was great. Unfortunately this means I am reaching the end of this show and I don‚Äôt have a next procedural lined up!!!

  • Dog has an ear infection and it‚Äôs incredibly gross. Golden Retrievers have a lot of ear.

  • I think the trick to ‚Äúexercising‚Äù is just living in yoga pants and sports bras. I am 100% more likely to exercise if I‚Äôm already dressed for it, because the thought of changing into yoga pants from whatever potato sack outfit I‚Äôm wearing just to go exercise seems daunting. Is this a life hack? Also, what is wrong with my brain that changing into different clothes seems like an unmeasurable amount of effort?

  • Actually don‚Äôt answer that.

entry.title: Week 17
entry.content:
• I‚Äôve been skipping weeks because a) literally nothing happens and b) I don‚Äôt have a good system to update these notes. They‚Äôre a markdown file on a GitHub repo, and I kind of need a computer to edit it, but I also kind of don‚Äôt open my computer that much these days? I also keep forgetting which day is Monday. Room for improvement.

  • I wrote a blog post about how I generated some tree rings in JavaScript and then carved them as a linocut. It doesn‚Äôt actually contain any JavaScript, but it does have a lot of pretty images.

  • The last normal thing I did before the panini started was go to Japantown and stock up on apocalypse supplies (snackos, mucho ramen, milk tea powder, korean face things). The first normal thing I did with my 1 vaccine shot was go to Japantown and restock all the things. This wasn‚Äôt on purpose, but I am pleased with the serendipity. It is cherry blossom season, so it was very pretty, HOWEVER, some racist asshole vandalized two of the oldest cherry trees there in January. Literally chopped down all of the branches, one at a time. What the actual fuck.

  • If you‚Äôre against plastic (why aren‚Äôt you?) and use deodorants, Dove has started selling refillable ones. I got mine from Target. The refill itself still comes in plastic, but overall it‚Äôs far less plastic than the obnoxious amount the normal ones have. I‚Äôm excited about this not because this deodorant is particularly amazing, but because Dove is a HUGE brand, and having mainstream brands start looking into more reusable, less-plastic products is a small but exciting progress.

  • Speaking of waste, Zach bought us me the most amazing thing: a foodcycler!!! We‚Äôve been composting for years, but I‚Äôve recently started getting lazier about putting the compost back in the freezer when I‚Äôm done with it, so our idiot dog has been stealing a lot of compost (which is full of bad things for her like coffee grounds, onion peels, literally half a spaghetti squash rind she ate and threw up for 8 hours). This foodcycler thing takes the compost and dehydrates it and grinds it and in 4 hours is done and gives you back fertilizer at like a tenth of the original volume. We‚Äôve had it for a week and it‚Äôs honestly THE MOST innovation I‚Äôve seen in my kitchen.

entry.title: Week 18
entry.content:
• Ya look at that? It‚Äôs May already. My dog‚Äôs is turning 2 on the 14th, does anyone have any good dog cake recipes or should I just give her an almost-empty jar of peanut butter with the same success rate?

  • I got my second fouchie outchie! (#teampfizer). I wouldn‚Äôt say it bodied me the next day, but I felt uncomfortable enough to sit in bed and read not one but TWO Bridgerton novels. I‚Äôve now read 1-4 and I think I‚Äôm done for a while.

  • Speaking of books, I‚Äôm finishing up On Earth We‚Äôre Briefly Gorgeous (Ocean Vuong; reads like poetry but isn‚Äôt. Review next time), and I‚Äôm about to start up The Vanishing Half (Brit Bennett; very 2021 book cover). I also finished a book in Romanian, translated from Russian: Zuleiha opens her eyes (Guzel Yakhina. Really beautiful, much more hopeful and uplifting than the Russian literature I‚Äôm used to.)

  • After 15+ years of living in North America, I think I am ‚Äúinto‚Äù oatmeal. Oatmeal isn‚Äôt a Romanian thing at all ‚Äì oats are for horses, cream of wheat is for babies, adults don‚Äôt eat either. Current approach: 1. overnight oats (in water, cashew milk makes them too‚Ä¶intense and I don‚Äôt give money to the meat industry for cow milk) + either apple sauce (that I make because I keep forgetting to eat apples), or frozen fruit.

  • Other food shit I‚Äôm obsessed with right now: ingesting industrial quantities of watermelon, these keto peanut butter cookies (I don‚Äôt eat keto, but pb cookies with no-guilt-sugar are delicius), cashew milk.

  • Arts: I am deeply struggling with a 3 layer linocut. I‚Äôve carved it like 3+ times, and no matter how I do it I can‚Äôt line up all the 3 layers well. I think it‚Äôs time to give up on it and make it into a digital print. Also, I‚Äôve been working on L-systems, which make pretty trees. Should I write a blog post about that when it‚Äôs done?

entry.title: Week 20
entry.content:
• normalcy resumes chez nous. I know this isn‚Äôt true everywhere, so if you‚Äôre in a place of lockdown: I am sorry for how annoying these updates will be. I was a good girl and bunkered down for over a year, and now I‚Äôve got antibodies in spades and taking advantage of it.
  • first trip of the after times: Monterey! I‚Äôd never been, because prior to last year we didn‚Äôt have a car, and renting a car for a 2 hour trip always felt daunting. However, now we have a car, and San Francisco is full of lovely things just a drive away.
  • aquarium is still on pandemic rules so I didn‚Äôt get to see any ü¶¶ü¶¶ü¶¶. Next time!
  • left Hopper at a dog boarding place for half a day so that we could have brunch in Carmel ‚Äúwithout the kids‚Äù. First, paying for eggs I didn‚Äôt cook was an incredible experience and I almost cried (this is a theme this month, every time I do something that was pedestrian and normal in the before times I get overwhelmed with emotion). Second, Hopper a) fooled the humans into somehow trusting she‚Äôs not a vacuum cleaner and promptly ate another dog‚Äôs lunch and b) was a squirelly weirdo and mostly wanted to hang out around humans and not the other dogs, which is 60% her personality and 40% something she picked up in the apocalypse.
  • had an indoor fancy dinner with fellow vaccinated friends, to celebrate our new superpowers, and the place had white Russian ice cream floats for desert and can I just say: yes.
  • EUROVISION. Incredible showings from Iceland and Ukraine, and an absolute shit bouquet when it came to voting. Collusion has been a Eurovision classic since the dawn of time, but this year it was enraging. France, really? Discount Edith Piaf? What a travesty. Special mention however to the international conspiracy of letting the UK go to the final only to award them 0 points across the board. A masterpiece; well done everyone.

entry.title: Week 21
entry.content:
• Chopped off 10 inches of my hair and I feel unstoppable. I always think I can deal with mermaid hair when the reality is I cba to brush it and it keeps getting longer and drier until I‚Äôm ready to take the kitchen scissors to it. I resisted that impulse and got a professional to cut it. Am I finally an adult?
  • I am writing this update FROM A PLANE. Yes, a real plane. My brother-in-law‚Äôs family is moving into a new house and we‚Äôre going to celebrate. Also I haven‚Äôt seen their kids in a year and a half, which is 50% of one of them‚Äôs lives. She talks now! What!
  • Update: the inner life of 3 year olds is outstanding. We are just guests in their world.
  • Books: I finished the Vanishing Half and it was Very Good. I mostly avoided reading it because it has the most 2020 book style cover I‚Äôve ever seen, but it was quite good despite that. Some weeks back I also finished On earth We‚Äôre Briefly Gorgeous and it was a bit of a miss for me. I like everything it was about (love a good immigrant memoir) but I didn‚Äôt enjoy the writing, which made the actual reading time a bit of a slog. I‚Äôm now reading The Lies of Locke Lamora because TikTok told me about it.
  • Jake did a lot of walking for cancer (he‚Äôs against). He walked 100km in a row, in something like over 24h. As part of it he also did an hourly ama (or at least until he became a delirious shell of a man), and Frances and I (henceforth known as the chuckle sisters) covered 6 shifts. It was good fun and I‚Äôm enormously proud of him.
  • One of the best things about having a FitBit smart watch instead of an Apple one is that I can make my own faces really easily (in JavaScript!!!). I wanted something that looked very clean on the main screen but also had the option for a stats heavy second screen, and I could never find quite the right one so I made my own. Putting this work experience to good use!

entry.title: Week 22: a week of sports
entry.content:
• Trying out titles because I have enough weeks that even I can‚Äôt tell them apart and I lived through them.
  • Sports!!! We went to the Nations League ‚öΩÔ∏è semis and finals in Denver. If you don‚Äôt know this about me, I am a bit of a football (soccer) hooligan. Zach and I go to games, we sit in suporter sections, we chant. We went to France for the Women‚Äôs World Cup, because sports is a great excuse to travel, and the US women‚Äôs team is rad af. On top of that, a weird goal of mine is to be one of the drummers doing the chant drum beats, so I was super happy I got to drum a couple of chants at both games! I even got a gnarly workplace injury blister this time! I think the next big international game is in Vegas, and this might be the one where I try to bring my very own snare drum? Stay tuned.
  • Colorado in general has given up on masks for the fully vaccinated, which is still so very strange to me. I ate indoors. I walked into a store without a mask on. I hugged friends I haven‚Äôt seen in a year. I hugged new friends I met in a bar.
  • We had 2 free days in between the semis and the final, so we went to Boulder! I hadn‚Äôt been before and I LOVED it. It‚Äôs so cute and chill. I would definitely be happy living there for a couple of years.
  • Books: I finished The Lies of Locke Lamora. It was an enjoyable story of thievery and shenanigans. I‚Äôm reading Midnight Library now and I am a bit worried because Laura (with who I usually agree on books) said she thought it was badly written, and I am a bit of a writing snob (eg I genuinely loved the writing style of The Starless Sea and a lot of people find that book unbearable).
  • I have updated my LinkedIn for the first time in over a decade. What a weird place that site is.

entry.title: Week 24: vroom vroom
entry.content:
• Weird flex: been making cheese fondue for lunch because I make the rules here.
  • One of the (many) amazing things about being a Canadian living in California is that this state (unlike, say, no-rules-nevada) doesn‚Äôt recognize non-US driving licenses. This means that after almost 20 years of getting my first driver‚Äôs license I had to do the whole circus show (written test, road test, being treated like a teenager, etc) to be able to drive here. This week I finally bit the bullet and a) drove daily which is wild and b) did my road test (passed with flying colours, I know you‚Äôre wondering). Side effect: I don‚Äôt have to use my Quebec license when I get IDed in bars and go through through the whole apology that my birthday is in fact in french. Bouncers love that.
  • Speaking of, I‚Äôve misplaced my Quebec licence and that‚Äôs very irritating.
  • Euro 2020 is on! As per, my heart team is the Netherlands and they‚Äôre doing surprisingly well! They‚Äôve been #blessed with a pretty easy group (rip group F) and I am not looking that gift horse in the mouth.
  • It‚Äôs a month that ends in y so I‚Äôm trying to redo my site. Inspos: I really like how clean Karolina‚Äôs is; I‚Äôm low key of obsessed with this absurd cursor from CDL.
  • There‚Äôs a bear in Tahoe that I‚Äôm 100% convinced is just trolling our dog. He spent a whole day casually pacing up and down next to our house, which sends Hopper into a fit of barking hysteria.
  • Books: I finished Midnight Library and really didn‚Äôt like it, and Convenience Store Woman and it reminded me a lot of absurd theatre plays. I‚Äôm starting Klara and the Sun now.

entry.title: Week 25: I redid my website
entry.content:
• It‚Äôs true, I did. I also wrote a blog post about it because tbh I did a good job on it, and it‚Äôs a good read.
  • As two ladies of leisure, Frances and I went to the MOMA on a weekday to see the new Nam June Paik exhibition. I didn‚Äôt love all of it, but the bits I really enjoyed were all about putting TVs in unexpected situations. Which makes sense, since I really enjoy when surrealism is executed well. I loved the TV garden which was a dark room of real life plants with a bunch of old school CRTs showing ‚Ä¶ weird ass videos; the TV cello and TV bra which are exactly what they say they are, and a bunch of TV sculptures, like this TV robot.
  • The museum still requires indoor masks, which I have nothing against but thought it was an interesting choice since most of SF has given up on indoor masks for the vaccinated and the whole point of museums is to like‚Ä¶ not touch anything, people or art. Anyway, I bought a dope book from the gift shop about architectural form that (as I am writing this entry 3 weeks later) I have yet to open.
  • Speaking of architectural form, the MOMA has a bonkers layout and I can never find the stairway that goes in the direction I need. I always end up wandering aimlessly around like a chicken. I have nothing against wandering aimlessly through a museum, I just don‚Äôt like it to be in a quest for stairs.
  • I bought a Diana Instant camera!!! Suz was the one who bought one first and tweeted about it, and it reminded me about how when I was poor in uni and ‚Äúinto photography‚Äù I was all about plastic leaky cameras (like Holgas and Dianas) but they were mad expensive and I needed to spend my money on predominantly food and wine. But now they‚Äôre an afforable price for adult Monica AND they‚Äôve made an instant version that works with the Instax film so you don‚Äôt have to wait for 3 weeks to see you took a tragically exposed photo. Suz and I are now having this paired adventure where we text each other bad photos and compare notes. It‚Äôs fun.

entry.title: Week 28: I did a vacation
entry.content:
• So here‚Äôs what happened: I went on vacation and because I‚Äôm leaning so hard into this funemployment life I didn‚Äôt open my laptop once.
  • Every year Zach and I go to his parents‚Äô (now my in-laws! hah!) lake in Minnesota for the 4th of July. Normally we fly there, but last year we drove (because of the panderoni) and this year we also drove because you can‚Äôt fly with a big dog anymore. It‚Äôs kind of a bummer, and I hope airlines revisit this decision and find a middle ground that works both for the rest of the plane and people with nice but big dogs that don‚Äôt fit under seats (like ‚Ä¶buying your dog their own seat. I‚Äôd be fine with that).
  • Anyway, this all to say: we drove for 3 days again from SF to Minnesota (and then 3 days back). This year was a bit easier because I (finally) got my US driver‚Äôs license so Zach didn‚Äôt have to drive 9 hour days by himself. Also we didn‚Äôt camp or stop for sightseeing because we‚Äôve exhausted everything of note in the middle of America.
  • Related: Montana is enormous. I feel we drove an entire day through Montana and there was still some Montana left.
  • Having now driven SEVERAL hours on the highway: truck drivers are wild. Some started signalling and pulling in my passing lane as I was trying to pass them; some do dick moves like drive parallel with another truck so nobody can pass them; almost none of them respect the 55 speed limit in construction zones. Rules? Who is she.
  • Something I should‚Äôve predicted is that I emotionally implode with anxiety while driving thinking that the people behind me are judging me. Do they think I‚Äôm weak because I‚Äôm only driving the posted limit in this construction zone? Don‚Äôt they know fines double?? Should I be speeding? I know I‚Äôm driving a Tesla but I‚Äôm an old woman at heart who would love it if we could all just follow the rules, ok?
  • Both the dog and I had a great time at the lake. She spent all day in the lake swimming and playing with my 5 year old nephew; she also tried to play with the A, 3 year old, but their motor skills didn‚Äôt match well. A would try to throw a buoy for her, but she couldn‚Äôt throw it well, so Hopper thought this was actually an invitation to play tug and would accidentally hip check A, who would then trip, drop the buoy, get excited, pick up the buoy again and repeat this until bored. Hopper was exhausted every night and slept like a rock. I also slept like a rock because kids babysat my dog and unlike previous years I had zero work stress on my soul.
  • I read nonstop while sat in the sun with industrial amounts of sun screen on. I did my yearly penance of watching nightly baseball because it was on, saw the Habs make it and then lose the Stanley cup (it‚Äôs fine, I‚Äôm not heartbroken), watched (on purpose) the Euros and Wimbledon, ate a lot of cheese curds.
  • Books: Parable of the Sower (loved it, strangely apropos for 2020s fire and drought California), The invisible life of Addie Larue (TikTok made me read it, great beach read), Klara and the Sun (allegedly a sci-fi but not in like a Dune or aliens kind of way), Little Weirds (did not finish it; didn‚Äôt enjoy the writing style AND my book was badly bound making it a frustrating discovery). I‚Äôm now reading Homegoing which is shaping up to be great.
  • A weird thing that happened on the drive back is that I had a medium-bad allergy to (I think) peanut butter. I broke out in hives and now I need to either get that shit checked out or do another test at home with an epi-pen nearby because in general only bad things follow hives. Ugh.
  • Did y‚Äôall have a summer break? Was it good? Maybe tell me about it on Twitter?

entry.title: Week 29: I do some actual work for a change
entry.content:
• First off: I think I‚Äôve done a bad numbering in some of these recent weeks, because I wanted to write about what I actually did on July 13/14, but apparently I‚Äôve already counted that week? Counting, man, a hell of a thing.
  • My good friend Maeghan who aside from being a top drawer human being and tswift fan is an amazing professional contact (and I don‚Äôt deserve her one bit), connected me with the European Innovation Academy (EIA) to do some technical mentoring for them. They run a pretty neat incubator-like program, where they teach university students how to get from startup idea to feature work, to sort-of implementing and finally pitching to VCs
  • I was a bit terrified of doing this because I think of myself as having no startup experience, but it turns out a lot of the things I learnt running small projects inside of Google really apply and I was kind of really good at it? I know, self confidence, who saw this coming.
  • Related: I‚Äôm trying to be a little less self-deprecating professionally. I deal with social anxiety by telling jokes and being wildly self-deprecating, but I‚Äôve noticed when people just meet me and don‚Äôt know me at all, they don‚Äôt know I‚Äôm joking and I come off like an incompetent weirdo. This is a big change for me because I hate confrontation and being assertive, but I need people to know I am actually a badass. C‚Äôest la vie.
  • Observed anecdote: the teams that were predominantly women were on top of their shit and kicked ass. The teams that were predominantly men, OR had a very loud and uninformed men in charge were super behind and not doing super well. This makes sense because we know women are particularly good at organization and doing homework, but tragic because we also don‚Äôt have a ton of women leading startups.
  • We were in Tahoe for the week and my local friend Jessica somehow tricked me to go to 3 (THREE) days of yoga classes. Two of them were hot and disgusting, and one of them was aerial! What‚Äôs even more disgusting than the amount of sweating that I did is that I enjoyed them? Who am i.

entry.title: Week 30: this little drummer girl
entry.content:
• On Monday Frances took me to the teamLab exhibition at the Asian Art museum. It was really wonderful! I hadn‚Äôt seen the one in Japan so I was new to it, but the interactive art nerd in me was all over the concept and trying to figure out what was static and what was interactive, and where the sensors were. Tons of fun!
  • On the weekend we went to the Gold Cup ‚öΩÔ∏è final in Vegas. This is important only because: the powers that be let me bring my own drum and I drummed for the whole 120 minutes. As I might have mentioned this has been a dream of mine, and I‚Äôm 100% that dream-believe-achieve bitch. I still need to improve a lot, and bless Ryan (who played the big boi drum next to me) who had to put up with me coming in sliiiightly too early a lot. Only up from here!
  • Looking at my calendar, a lot of my funemployment is spent levelling up. This will not shock anyone but: I kind of loved school. My first 2 years in uni I audited like 2 or 3 extra classes a semester, because I‚Äôd get all the bits I loved (going to class, learning things, taking notes), and none of the existential dread and panic attacks of being evaluated. So now that I‚Äôm an adult who gets to control how I learn things, I‚Äôm all over it. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs currently on the docket:
  • Practicing drum rudiments on my snare drum. I should probably find a human to pay to help me with this, since I‚Äôm figuring it all out from YouTube and tbh, I have some questions.
  • Singing classes. I really enjoy singing in the car but I a) don‚Äôt like the sound of my voice and b) don‚Äôt actually like to produce loud sounds that draw attention to me, both of which make me not want to sing along in front of people. A lot of singing is relearning how to breathe, and that is Extremely Weird.
  • Spanish on Duolingo. I used to speak it as a kid (I used to watch a lot of telenovelas, and I‚Äôm a bit of a language sponge), but I lost it since I never actually used it. I want to be able to speak to my friend‚Äôs Colombian family when we go to their wedding, so here I am.
  • Conversational French hangouts on italki. French and I have a super uncomfortable relationship where after 11 years in Montreal I understand and can read most of it, but I‚Äôm unable to speak it. It‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt know what to say, it‚Äôs that I literally panic and refuse to say the words. I‚Äôve had a lot of kind of traumatic experiences with a bunch of french (and quebecois) native speakers who were really hostile to people who speak French poorly, and it left me a bit terrified of even trying. I figured the best I can do to work on it is pay a complete stranger to talk to me ‚Äì even if they think I‚Äôm shit, I won‚Äôt ever see them in person. I will be able to sleep at night just fine.
  • Books: I am struggling with Homegoing by Yaa Gyasi, because it‚Äôs a devastating book. It‚Äôs well written and I desperately want to finish, but I find myself dreading reading it; all the stories are about horrible things that people did to slaves and my heart just breaks on every page.

entry.title: Week 32: putting these on pause
entry.content:
It‚Äôs been one week since you looked at me 8 months since I‚Äôve been writing these weekly notes, and I think I‚Äôm going to take a small break from it. It‚Äôs been a good experiment, but I‚Äôve been getting sloppy with remembering they‚Äôre due, and it‚Äôs starting to feel a bit self-indulgent. Because I don‚Äôt actually advertise that they exist, I don‚Äôt think anyone reads them, so I‚Äôm not entirely sure why I‚Äôm writing them if nobody on either side of the fence is particularly amused by the experience. I do have a blog post in the barrel which is a rare and momentuous occasion y‚Äôall can look forward to.

xoxo, monica
